alt_statements.statement: As someone who’s seen both economic struggle and the real impacts of pollution in my community, I don’t think it’s a choice between the environment and jobs—we need policies that do both. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive environmental protection, but it has to be paired with investment in green jobs, public transit, and energy-efficient housing so working-class and low-income people aren’t left behind. If we plan it right, a clean energy transition can be a path to opportunity, not sacrifice, especially for places like Puerto Rico that are already on the frontlines of climate change.

As a husband and father working in manufacturing, I believe climate policy has to protect the environment without destroying the jobs and industries that support families like mine. We should invest in cleaner technologies and energy efficiency, but changes must be gradual, realistic, and guided by science and common sense, not ideology. If regulations become so strict that factories move overseas or shut down, we end up hurting both our economy and, in many cases, the global environment. The right balance is encouraging responsible stewardship of creation while keeping businesses competitive and workers employed.

As someone who works in the private sector and sees how financial decisions shape businesses, I believe environmental protection and economic growth must be aligned, not treated as opposing goals. Climate policy should push companies to reduce emissions and invest in clean technologies through clear regulations and incentives, even if it means short-term costs, because long-term stability—economic and environmental—depends on a livable planet. From a justice perspective, we also have a responsibility to ensure that the costs of transitioning to a green economy don’t fall disproportionately on low-income communities and workers.

I think we must care for the earth because it is God’s creation and the place our grandchildren will live, but we also have to be careful not to destroy people’s ability to make an honest living. Policies should protect clean air, water, and our changing climate, but they need to be gradual and practical so factories, small businesses, and workers are not pushed into poverty. Responsible companies that reduce pollution should be supported, and help should be given to workers and communities so they can adjust without losing everything.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if the planet gets too messed up, there won’t be a good future for any jobs or money anyway. Grown-ups and companies should still be able to make money, but they should have to follow rules that stop them from polluting too much, even if it costs more. It seems better to think long-term and keep the air, water, and climate safe so kids like me can grow up healthy and still have chances to work and create things.

As a medical research scientist, I see climate policy first and foremost as a public health intervention: environmental degradation directly drives disease, strain on healthcare systems, and long‑term economic instability. Economic growth that depends on high emissions is, biologically speaking, a short‑lived gain with severe downstream costs, so our priority should be aggressive emissions reductions and ecosystem protection, paired with targeted investment in green industries and worker retraining. In other words, we shouldn’t be trading health for GDP; we should be redefining growth so that clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and low‑carbon innovation are the engines of a healthier, more sustainable economy.

As someone who cares a lot about the environment and plans to live on this planet for many decades, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, but not in a way that ignores people’s jobs and basic needs. Instead of treating the environment and the economy like opposites, we should invest in clean energy, green infrastructure, and retraining programs so that workers and communities—especially those already struggling—benefit from the transition. In the long run, a healthy economy depends on a healthy planet, so real economic growth has to be sustainable, not based on burning through resources and worsening climate change.

My mom and dad say we have to take care of the Earth because God made it, like how we have to clean up our toys after we play. I think grown-ups should make rules so the air and water stay clean, even if it costs money, because kids need a safe place to play when we get bigger. But they should also help people keep their jobs so families can still buy food and toy cars and be okay while we fix the planet.

As someone who manages a grocery store and sees firsthand how supply chains, food prices, and jobs depend on a stable environment, I think climate policy has to treat environmental protection and economic growth as linked, not competing goals. We should aggressively invest in clean energy, efficiency, and sustainable agriculture, because those create good jobs and protect the communities and workers who’ll be hit hardest by climate change. I’d rather see smart regulations and incentives that help businesses adapt and innovate than short-term profits that leave us with higher costs and harsher impacts down the road.

Climate policy has to protect our land and communities, but it can’t cripple the economy or punish working families and small businesses in the process. I support reasonable, evidence-based environmental regulations that encourage innovation and cleaner technology, but I don’t believe in extreme measures that kill jobs, raise energy prices, or put us at a disadvantage against countries like China. The right balance is investing in practical solutions—like improving grid reliability, supporting nuclear and natural gas, and incentivizing businesses to cut emissions—without overregulating or growing government control.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we ruin the planet there won’t be any economy left for my generation to grow up in. That said, climate policies should also help create new kinds of jobs and technologies so people don’t lose their livelihoods. We should invest in clean energy, public transit, and greener businesses, so we can cut pollution while still letting communities and families like mine have stable futures.

As someone who spent a lifetime organizing in the community, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as enemies, but I do think the planet’s limits have to set the rules of the game. We should invest heavily in clean energy, public transit, and green jobs so working families—especially in Latino and immigrant neighborhoods—can benefit from the transition instead of being left behind. If we damage the climate beyond repair, any short-term economic gains won’t mean much to our grandchildren, so growth has to serve sustainability and justice, not the other way around.

As someone who spent a career in banking and management, I believe we need a pragmatic, market-driven approach to climate policy that protects the environment without strangling economic growth. We should encourage innovation in cleaner technologies and support reasonable regulations that safeguard our air and water, but avoid heavy-handed mandates and new taxes that punish businesses and working families. A strong, growing economy gives us the resources to invest in environmental solutions, so the goal should be smart, balanced policies that keep American industry competitive while being good stewards of God’s creation.

As someone who does hands-on work in buildings every day, I see how much energy we waste and how small changes—better insulation, smarter lighting, efficient systems—can cut costs and pollution at the same time. We shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; smart climate policy can create good, stable jobs, especially in building retrofits and green infrastructure, while protecting the communities we live in. As a liberal Democrat and a Jew, I feel a moral responsibility to care for the earth and for vulnerable people who’ll be hit hardest by climate change. So I support aggressive climate action that invests in clean technology, worker protections, and community-based programs, even if it means short-term costs for long-term justice and prosperity.

I believe we have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to protect the environment, but we have to do it in a way that doesn’t crush jobs, small businesses, or folks on fixed incomes like mine. Climate policy should encourage American innovation—nuclear power, cleaner natural gas, advanced renewables, and better efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that handicap our economy while countries like China pollute freely. We ought to move toward cleaner energy gradually and sensibly, keeping energy affordable and our economy strong, so our grandchildren inherit both a healthy planet and a prosperous nation.

I think we’ve got to protect the land and water God gave us, but we can’t do it in a way that destroys people’s jobs and drives up prices for working folks like me. Climate policy should focus on practical steps—like encouraging cleaner technology and energy efficiency—without piling on regulations that crush small businesses and restaurants already struggling to get by. Environmental rules ought to be based on solid evidence, rolled out gradually, and balanced so regular workers don’t end up paying the price for decisions made by people who never worried about a grocery bill.

I think we should protect nature first, because if the air and water get too dirty, people and animals will get sick and we won’t have a nice world to grow up in. Grown-ups can still make money by making cleaner things, like cars that don’t pollute as much and houses that use less energy, so the economy can grow in a way that doesn’t hurt the planet.

At this stage of my life, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals so much as badly managed priorities. Climate policy should put strong, enforceable environmental standards first and then spur innovation and good jobs—especially in clean energy and resilient infrastructure—within those guardrails. We’ve let short‑term profits drive decisions for too long, and it’s time to accept that a stable climate and healthy communities are the foundation of any durable, fair economy.

At my age, I’ve seen how chasing short-term economic gains without regard for the environment always seems to leave ordinary people paying the price later. I believe climate policy should put environmental protection first, with smart, steady investments in clean energy and infrastructure that also create good jobs and help communities—especially those with fewer resources—transition fairly. Economic growth that destroys the planet we leave to our grandchildren isn’t really “growth” at all; it’s a debt we’re passing on.

As a working single mom and property manager, I see both sides of this issue every day: people need good jobs and affordable places to live, but we also need clean air, water, and a stable climate for our kids’ future. Climate policy should treat environmental protection and economic growth as linked, not competing—investing in energy-efficient buildings, green infrastructure, and clean tech can create solid middle-class jobs while cutting emissions. We should hold big polluters accountable and offer incentives and support for businesses and property owners to go greener, especially in working- and middle-class communities. That’s the kind of practical, long-term balance that actually helps families like mine instead of just protecting short-term profits.

We need to protect the environment, but we can’t cripple the economy or people’s ability to earn a living in the process. Climate policy should focus on practical steps—like cleaner technology and better efficiency in factories—without piling on regulations and costs that send jobs overseas or shut down plants. I’m fine with reasonable rules that keep the air and water clean, but they need to be gradual, realistic, and support American workers first.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because if we ruin the planet now, there won’t be a real future for any kind of economy. But I also know families need jobs and money to live, so climate policies should push for clean energy and green jobs that help communities, especially Black communities that already face more pollution. Instead of acting like it’s either the Earth or the economy, we should invest in solutions that protect nature while creating new kinds of work and opportunities.

As someone who’s built a livelihood running a small consulting business, I believe climate policy has to protect our environment without crippling the economy or punishing job creators. We should focus on practical, market-based solutions and incentives for innovation—especially in American industry—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive costs up for families and small businesses. Protecting the earth is part of our duty as stewards of God’s creation, but that stewardship should respect people’s need to work, invest, and grow. A balanced approach means gradual, realistic targets and policies that keep the U.S. competitive while encouraging cleaner, more efficient technologies.

I don’t think we should have to choose between a decent job and a livable planet, especially when people my age are the ones who’ll deal with the worst of climate change. Working construction, I see how much money gets thrown around on big projects, so there’s no excuse not to invest in cleaner tech, better building standards, and green jobs that still pay well. Climate policy should put strict limits on pollution and carbon, but also help workers and companies transition so regular people don’t get screwed while we clean things up.

Working in community outreach in the film industry, I see firsthand how powerful stories can shift public attitudes, and I think climate policy needs to clearly prioritize environmental protection while supporting workers and local communities through the transition. Economic growth that destroys ecosystems or worsens climate change isn’t real prosperity—it just pushes costs onto vulnerable people and future generations. We should invest heavily in clean energy, green jobs, and sustainable infrastructure so that economic opportunity and environmental responsibility reinforce each other instead of being treated as opposites.

For me, the land is like a canvas we all share, and if we ruin it, there is no way to paint it back the same. I think we have to protect nature first, but in a way that doesn’t crush small workers and people like me who barely make enough. Good climate policies should help us use cleaner tools and methods without making it impossible to earn a living, so we can keep working with dignity while caring for God’s creation.

As a software developer who cares a lot about innovation, I think we’re framing this question the wrong way when we treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals. If we invest heavily in clean energy, smarter infrastructure, and climate-friendly technologies, we can create high-quality jobs and new industries while cutting emissions. As a left-leaning Catholic, I also feel a moral responsibility to protect creation and the most vulnerable people, who are hit hardest by climate change. So climate policy should be aggressive on environmental standards, but designed to support workers and businesses in transitioning to a low-carbon economy, not simply punish them.

As someone who makes a living in tech and cares about innovation, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—in the long run, a stable climate is a prerequisite for a stable economy. We should invest aggressively in clean energy, modern infrastructure, and green tech, using market incentives and strong regulations to push businesses toward sustainability without killing opportunity. I’d rather see us lead in building the next generation of climate-friendly technologies than cling to outdated industries that put both our health and our future at risk.

I believe we have a duty to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t cripple our economy or burden working families and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate policies should focus on practical, cost‑effective steps—like improving energy efficiency, supporting cleaner technology, and encouraging innovation in the private sector—without heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs or drive up energy prices. The right balance is protecting the environment while keeping America strong, competitive, and affordable for ordinary citizens.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put off taking care of things, and the planet is no different—if we don’t protect the environment now, there won’t be much “economy” left for the next generations. I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, but it also needs to support working people and small businesses like my little salon with help to transition—affordable clean energy, grants, and incentives to make greener choices. Economic growth is important, but it should come from cleaner, smarter work, not from cutting corners on the air we breathe and the water we drink.

I believe we should protect the environment, but not in a way that destroys people’s livelihoods or drives up prices for working families. Climate policies ought to encourage practical solutions—like cleaner technology, better energy efficiency, and incentives for businesses to innovate—rather than heavy-handed regulations and taxes. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still allowing our economy to grow and our communities to thrive.

Working in manufacturing, I see firsthand how regulations can feel like a burden, but I also see how much waste and energy we burn through, and I don’t think we can just ignore that for the sake of short-term profit. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with strong standards, but pair that with incentives and support to help companies modernize—especially in places like North Carolina where good jobs matter. If we invest in cleaner tech and energy efficiency, we can protect the places I love to hike and still grow the economy in a more sustainable way.

I think we’ve got to stop acting like protecting the environment and growing the economy are enemies—if anything, wrecking the planet is the fastest way to wreck the economy too. Climate policy should put strong limits on pollution and support clean energy and green jobs, even if that means big corporations have to sacrifice profits in the short term. We should invest in tech, public transit, and sustainable infrastructure so people can still have opportunities and good lives without cooking the planet for my generation and the ones after.

As a physician, I see every day how health is inseparable from the environment we live in—air quality, heat, and pollution all show up in my patients’ charts—so I can’t accept the idea that economic growth should come at the cost of a livable planet. My faith and humanitarian values push me toward policies that aggressively reduce emissions and protect vulnerable communities, while still supporting innovation, green jobs, and just transitions for workers. We should treat environmental protection as a non‑negotiable foundation and design our economy around it, not the other way around.

Working in local government, I see every day that a healthy environment and a healthy economy aren’t opposites—they depend on each other. Climate policy should prioritize protecting air, water, and long‑term ecological stability, but do so in a way that supports steady, predictable economic transitions for workers and small businesses. I’d rather see us invest in resilient infrastructure, energy efficiency, and green jobs now than pay far more later in disaster response and lost productivity. Thoughtful, data-driven policy can respect both our responsibility to the community and the need for economic stability.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how our environment shapes people’s bodies and minds, I don’t think environmental protection and economic growth should be treated as competing goals. Climate policy should put planetary and community health first, and then build economic growth around that through green jobs, clean energy, and support for workers and small businesses making the transition. Long term, an economy that destroys its environmental foundation is neither ethical nor stable—real prosperity means clean air, safe water, and resilient communities for everyone.

As someone who works in science and is immersed in technology, I think the supposed trade-off between environmental protection and economic growth is often overstated—long-term economic stability depends on a livable planet. Climate policy should aggressively cut emissions and protect ecosystems, while channeling public investment into clean energy, research, and green infrastructure that can drive innovation, create skilled jobs, and reduce inequality. From a progressive and faith-informed perspective, we have a moral responsibility to steward creation responsibly, which means prioritizing sustainability even if it requires short-term economic adjustments.

At my age, having watched rivers I knew as a girl run lower and summers grow harsher, it’s clear to me that economic growth built on a ruined climate is a false prosperity. We should treat environmental protection as the frame within which all responsible economic activity must fit, not an optional constraint to be bargained away. That means investing aggressively in clean energy, conservation, and green jobs, even if it slows or reshapes traditional growth, because the true economy we bequeath is the stability of air, water, and land our grandchildren will depend on.

As someone who’s worked my whole life and lives simply, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need policies that create good, stable jobs while cleaning up the air and water in our communities, especially Black communities that have carried the burden of pollution for decades. Climate policy should prioritize a just transition: investing in renewable energy, public transit, and healthcare jobs so workers aren’t left behind, and making sure corporations, not everyday people, bear the biggest cost of change.

I believe we need to protect God’s creation, but we also have to be realistic about how new rules affect working folks like me who rely on our cars to earn a living. Climate policies should focus on practical steps—like improving fuel efficiency and supporting cleaner technology—without killing jobs or driving up costs so much that people on modest incomes can’t afford to get by.

As someone who works in public education and spends most of my free time in nature, I believe strong environmental protection has to be the starting point, not an afterthought, in climate policy. That said, I don’t think protecting the environment and economic growth are opposites—if we invest in clean energy, green infrastructure, and resilient communities, we can create good, stable jobs while cutting emissions. Local and federal policies should prioritize long-term sustainability over short-term profit, especially for working families and public services like schools that will bear the costs of climate disasters.

As someone who cares deeply about both my community and the future my generation leaves behind, I believe climate policy has to put environmental protection front and center while actively supporting workers and businesses through a fair transition. We can’t keep treating economic growth as an excuse to delay action; instead, we should invest in clean energy, green manufacturing, and retraining programs that create good jobs and healthier communities. Protecting the environment and growing the economy aren’t opposites if we’re willing to plan long-term and hold corporations accountable for their impact.

I think we should protect nature a lot because it’s like our shared home that God gave us, and once it’s really damaged, we can’t fix it easily. Grown-ups should still care about jobs and money, but they should make rules so companies have to use clean energy and not pollute so much, even if it costs more at first. If we take care of the environment now, we’ll still have forests, animals, and clean air when we’re older, and that will help the economy in the long run too.

At my age, I’ve seen enough Minnesota winters to know the climate is changing, and we can’t pretend that endless economic growth matters more than clean air, safe water, and a livable planet for our grandchildren. I think we should treat environmental protection as a non-negotiable foundation, then design smart, gradual transitions—like investing in green jobs, better transit, and energy-efficient homes—so that workers, farmers, and small businesses aren’t left behind. Real prosperity, as I see it, means healthy communities, good schools, and a stable climate, not just short-term profits.

Climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because if we wreck the climate, the economy and our health both go down with it. That said, we should push hard for clean energy, efficiency, and green infrastructure that create stable, decent-paying jobs so working people don’t get left behind. I’d rather see us invest in long-term sustainability—better air, water, and public transit—than protect short-term profits for a few big companies.

I think we need a climate policy that protects our land and resources without strangling the economy or killing good-paying jobs, especially in industries like construction. We should focus on practical steps—like encouraging cleaner technologies, better building standards, and responsible energy use—without piling on regulations that make it impossible for working people to get ahead.

As a business manager, a dad, and an immigrant who chose this country, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need climate policy that aggressively cuts emissions while driving innovation, better jobs, and long‑term competitiveness. I’d rather see us invest in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and science‑driven standards now than saddle my kids with the costs of climate disasters later, both moral and financial.

I think we’ve got to protect the environment, but we can’t do it in a way that crushes working families and small businesses. Climate policy should focus on practical steps like encouraging cleaner technology, improving efficiency, and supporting American energy production, not piling on regulations that cost jobs and drive up utility bills. If we’re smart, we can grow the economy, keep power affordable, and still leave cleaner air and land for our kids.

I believe we need a balanced approach that protects our environment without crippling the businesses and workers our communities depend on. Climate policies should focus on encouraging innovation, energy efficiency, and American-made solutions rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up prices and cost people their jobs. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still supporting strong economic growth, especially for small towns and working families.

As someone who works in local government and sees firsthand how policy affects our schools and neighborhoods, I believe climate policy has to treat environmental protection and economic growth as partners, not opponents. We should invest in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs in ways that create opportunities—especially in communities that have been left behind—while setting strong but predictable standards for emissions. If we’re smart, we can grow our economy by preparing our kids for the jobs of the future, improving public health, and protecting the places we call home.

At my age, I’ve seen what unrestrained economic growth can do to both communities and the landscapes that inspire my art, and it’s not pretty. We need to treat environmental protection as the foundation of economic policy, not an accessory to it—investing in clean energy, public transit, and green jobs that give people real work without poisoning the air and water. There will be costs and disruptions, but they’re far smaller than the price my generation is leaving to the next if we keep stalling. A healthy economy that destroys its environment is like a beautiful painting left out in the rain—eventually, there’s nothing of value left.

I think we need to protect the land and air God gave us, but we’ve also got to be realistic about the jobs and bills people have right now. I work in construction and know a lot of guys who’d be out of work if we rush into extreme climate rules without thinking through the impact on working folks. To me, the right balance is investing in cleaner, more efficient technologies and building practices, offering incentives instead of heavy-handed mandates, and making sure any climate policy doesn’t crush small businesses or drive up energy costs for regular people.

As someone who loves being outdoors and wants my kids to grow up enjoying clean air, parks, and nature, I believe protecting the environment is important—but it has to be done in a way that doesn’t crush jobs or raise costs so much that working families can’t keep up. Climate policy should encourage innovation in cleaner energy, support responsible use of our natural resources, and rely on local and private-sector solutions rather than heavy-handed federal regulations.

“Growth for growth’s sake is the ideology of the cancer cell,” as Edward Abbey said, and that’s not a model we can afford for the planet. I think climate policy has to treat environmental protection as the non‑negotiable floor—strong emissions cuts, habitat protection, and a rapid transition to clean energy—while letting economic growth happen within those ecological limits. The good news is that a green economy can be more innovative, more resilient, and ultimately more prosperous, but we have to be honest that some industries will need to shrink or transform and we must support workers through that transition. Environmental safeguards shouldn’t be bent to fit short‑term profit; the economy should be redesigned to thrive inside a livable climate.

As a mom trying to raise kids on a cashier’s paycheck, I care a lot about the environment, but I can’t support climate policies that kill jobs or make energy and everyday goods too expensive for working families. We should focus on practical solutions—like encouraging businesses to innovate cleaner technologies and use energy more efficiently—without heavy-handed government mandates or regulations that hurt small towns and middle- and lower-income workers. In my view, protecting God’s creation and supporting economic growth can go hand in hand if we put American workers and families first in any climate plan.

As a mother and a homemaker, I want clean air, safe water, and a stable climate for my kids, but I also know families like mine depend on steady jobs and affordable energy. I believe we should support practical, market-based solutions—like incentives for cleaner technologies, conservation, and responsible use of resources—without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for working families. To me, the right balance is encouraging innovation and personal responsibility, not heavy-handed regulations that hurt our economy and our communities.

As someone who tries to live simply and be mindful of the environment, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because without a livable planet, any economic growth is meaningless. That said, we can and should design green policies that create good jobs and lower costs for regular people, especially families like mine living on limited incomes. Investments in clean energy, public transit, and energy efficiency can protect the Earth while also helping communities that are struggling economically.

As someone who believes strongly in individual freedom and personal responsibility, I think climate policy should protect the environment without strangling the economy or piling on regulations that crush small businesses like mine. We should prioritize market-driven innovation—cleaner technologies, better efficiency, and incentives for voluntary action—over heavy-handed mandates. Environmental protection matters, but it has to be balanced with job creation and economic growth so people can thrive while we transition to a cleaner future.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be any economy left to grow. But I also think we can use science, technology, and good education to create new kinds of jobs that don’t hurt the climate as much. Instead of acting like we have to choose between the Earth and money, we should be smart and figure out ways to do both more responsibly.

I think we should protect the Earth first, because if the air and water get ruined, people and animals can’t live healthy lives or have good jobs anyway. Grown‑ups should still try to make money and build cool things, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the planet so much, like using cleaner energy and not wasting stuff.

I don’t understand climate policy yet, but the grown‑ups who love me keep saying the world I grow up in needs clean air, safe water, and a stable climate more than it needs quick money. Protecting the environment should come first, and then we can build an economy that creates jobs and opportunities without hurting the planet, especially for kids like me who will live with the consequences the longest.

I think climate policy should treat environmental protection as the non‑negotiable foundation for any kind of real, long‑term economic growth. Where I live, people’s jobs and small businesses depend on stable weather and healthy land, so it’s short‑sighted to act like it’s “economy versus environment” when destroying the environment eventually wrecks the economy too. We should invest in cleaner technologies, renewable energy, and community-level projects that create jobs now while protecting the world my generation is going to inherit.

As someone who works in finance and values both long-term stability and social responsibility, I see environmental protection and economic growth as mutually reinforcing rather than competing goals. Climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and invest in clean energy and resilient infrastructure, while using market-based tools and smart regulation to drive innovation and protect jobs. If we internalize environmental costs and plan ahead, we can grow the economy in a way that safeguards public health, preserves creation, and avoids much higher financial and human costs down the road.

As someone who worked hard to build a modest living and values personal responsibility, I believe climate policy must protect the environment without punishing working families or stifling small businesses. We should focus on practical, market-driven solutions—like incentives for cleaner technology and responsible energy use—rather than heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs. Economic growth is not the enemy; it’s what funds innovation, infrastructure, and the social safety nets people rely on. A balanced approach respects both God’s creation and people’s need for opportunity and security.

My mommy says the air and the trees have to stay healthy so we don’t get sick and so the animals have homes, and I think that’s more important than making a lot of money. Grown‑ups should make things like cars and houses in ways that don’t make the sky dirty, even if it’s a little harder or slower, because God made the world and we have to take care of it.

I’m tired of hearing that we have to choose between the planet and people’s livelihoods—especially in working-class and Hispanic communities like mine that already feel the worst of pollution and heat. We need strong environmental protections and serious climate action, but done in a way that creates good, local jobs, invests in clean energy in our neighborhoods, and doesn’t leave retirees, low-income families, or workers behind. Real economic growth today should mean healthier air, lower energy bills, and safer communities for our kids and grandkids, not just higher profits for big corporations.

As someone working in tech and planning to be in the workforce for decades, I think climate policy has to prioritize environmental protection first, because the economic growth we care about isn’t worth much on a destabilized planet. That said, I don’t see this as a zero-sum tradeoff: smart regulation, carbon pricing, and investment in clean infrastructure and innovation can create new industries and high-quality jobs, including in software and data. The balance, to me, is setting firm environmental limits and then using market mechanisms and technology to grow within those boundaries, rather than sacrificing the climate for short-term profits.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because God made the Earth and we’re supposed to take care of it, but I also know people need jobs and money to buy food and crayons and stuff. Grown‑ups should make rules so we use cleaner energy and don’t hurt animals or the air, and at the same time help people learn new kinds of work that don’t wreck the planet.

I don’t think it should be “environment vs. economy,” because if we wreck the environment, there won’t be a stable economy anyway. We should push hard on clean energy, public transit, and green tech so we can cut emissions and create new jobs at the same time, instead of clinging to old polluting industries. Climate policy should help workers transition, not just tell them to deal with it, but protecting the planet has to come first because my generation is the one that’s going to be stuck living with the consequences.

As someone who works in finance and cares about both innovation and long-term stability, I see strong climate policy as an economic opportunity, not a drag on growth. We should set ambitious, science-based emissions targets and then leverage markets—carbon pricing, green bonds, and clean-tech incentives—to drive capital into sustainable infrastructure and technologies. Cutting corners on environmental protection just creates bigger risks and costs down the line, from supply chain disruptions to stranded assets. The right balance is leaning decisively into decarbonization while using smart policy design to support workers and encourage private-sector innovation.

As someone who came from Haiti and has seen firsthand how environmental degradation can devastate poor communities, I believe protecting the climate must be the starting point, not an afterthought, in economic policy. We should invest heavily in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs so that growth lifts people up without sacrificing the health of our planet or our neighborhoods. A just climate policy must prioritize vulnerable communities—both here and abroad—so that the transition away from fossil fuels is fair, inclusive, and creates opportunity rather than hardship.

I don’t think it should be framed as choosing between the environment and the economy, because if we wreck the climate, regular folks like me on fixed incomes will suffer first and worst. We need strong environmental protections that push us toward clean energy, but we also have to make sure the jobs and training that come with that transition are truly accessible to working people and communities of color. Climate policy should invest in things like home weatherization, public transit, and green jobs so that protecting the planet also means lowering bills and creating opportunity.

As a science-minded teacher and lifelong Coloradan who spends her weekends watching birds and tending a garden, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we depend on healthy ecosystems for any real, lasting prosperity. Climate policy should put strong limits on pollution and invest aggressively in clean energy, public transit, and conservation, while supporting workers and communities through the transition with job training and fair wages. If we cut corners now for short-term profit, we’ll be handing our students a far more expensive and unstable future, both economically and ecologically.

As someone who worked for years in a profit-driven industry, I know economic growth matters, but I also know that without a stable climate and healthy environment, any “growth” is ultimately hollow. We should make environmental protection the non‑negotiable foundation of climate policy, and then design smart, market‑savvy measures—like clean energy investments, retraining programs, and incentives for green innovation—so that workers and communities share in the benefits. I’m willing to pay higher taxes and accept short‑term economic adjustments if it means we leave a livable planet and a fairer, cleaner economy behind.

I think we’ve got to protect the environment in a way that doesn’t crush regular families and small businesses, because people still need steady jobs and affordable energy. I’m fine with smart regulations and investments in cleaner technology, but they should be practical, phased in slowly, and not driven by political grandstanding. Climate policy ought to encourage innovation and conservation, while making sure energy bills and taxes don’t skyrocket for folks on fixed incomes like mine.

As someone who has spent a career in federal service and is raising a family, I believe climate policy must protect our environment without crippling the economy that supports working families. We should prioritize practical, market-driven solutions—like incentivizing cleaner technology and improving energy efficiency—over sweeping regulations that kill jobs or drive up costs. A strong economy gives us the resources to invest in environmental protection, so the goal should be sensible, balanced policies that safeguard both our natural resources and our long-term prosperity.

As someone who works for myself and is raising kids, I think climate policy has to protect both the planet and working families at the same time. We can’t ignore environmental damage, because my kids and our community will live with those consequences, but we also can’t pass laws that crush small businesses and workers. The right balance is investing in clean energy, green jobs, and support for small shops and low-income neighborhoods so that going green actually creates opportunity instead of taking it away.

I believe climate policy has to protect the environment without crippling the industries that keep people employed and the economy strong. We should back practical, market-driven solutions—like incentives for cleaner technologies in manufacturing and energy—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive jobs overseas. As a supervisor in metals and minerals, I see how realistic standards and gradual transitions can reduce emissions while keeping American businesses competitive. We have a responsibility, morally and for future generations, to be good stewards of the earth, but that stewardship has to be grounded in economic reality and technological feasibility.

I work in pest control and see every day how important a clean, safe environment is, but I also know that if businesses can’t afford to operate, people like me lose our jobs. Climate policy should push for practical, affordable steps—like improving energy efficiency and encouraging cleaner tech—without crushing small companies and driving up costs for working families. We ought to protect God’s creation, but in a way that respects hard work, economic growth, and doesn’t leave regular folks paying the price for decisions made far away from our day-to-day reality.

I believe we need a practical balance where we protect the environment without strangling the businesses and workers that keep our communities going. Climate policy should focus on common-sense measures—like improving efficiency, reducing waste, and encouraging innovation—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs and threaten jobs, especially in industries that depend on physical goods like mine. As a conservative and a Catholic, I see stewardship of the earth as important, but so is protecting people’s livelihoods and keeping our economy strong enough to support families and the vulnerable.
